hero.title: NYC Subway Map: Simple, Safe & Solo‑Traveler Friendly
hero.subtitle: Your quick guide to navigating NYC’s subway without confusion.

howToRead: Colors represent subway lines, not boroughs.
Letters and numbers indicate specific services.
Solid dots show local stops; hollow dots show express stops.
White/black circles indicate transfer points between lines.
Weekend service changes are common—always check the MTA app.

routes.title: JFK → Manhattan
bullets: Take the AirTrain to Jamaica Station.
Transfer to the E line toward Manhattan.
Get off at Midtown (34th St–Penn Station).
Avoid peak hours if carrying luggage.

routes.title: Times Square → Brooklyn Bridge
bullets: Take the downtown 4/5/6 line.
Ride to Brooklyn Bridge–City Hall.
Follow signs for the pedestrian walkway.
Best done during daylight for first‑timers.

routes.title: Midtown → Central Park
bullets: Take the N/Q/R/W or B/D lines uptown.
Exit at 57th St or 59th St–Columbus Circle.
Walk north into the park.
Great for early morning solo walks.

routes.title: Lower Manhattan → Williamsburg
bullets: Take the L train from 14th St–Union Square.
Ride to Bedford Ave.
Expect crowds on weekends.
Stay near conductor car at night.

routes.title: LaGuardia → Manhattan (Bus + Subway)
bullets: Take the Q70 SBS to Jackson Heights–Roosevelt Ave.
Transfer to the E/F/M/R lines.
Fastest route to Midtown.
Q70 has luggage racks and runs 24/7.

safety: Stand near the conductor’s car at night.
Avoid empty subway cars, even if they look convenient.
Keep your bag in front of you at all times.
Use Google Maps live navigation for real‑time alerts.
Avoid the last car late at night.
Safest stations for solo travelers: Times Square–42nd St, 34th St–Penn Station, Fulton Center (all with high visibility, staff presence, and good lighting).

do: Let riders exit before you board.
Move to the center of the car.
Have your OMNY or MetroCard ready.
dont: Don’t eat messy or strong‑smelling food.

accessibility.title: Stations with Elevators
accessibility.content: Major hubs like Times Square, Fulton Center, and 34th St–Hudson Yards offer full accessibility.

accessibility.title: Wheelchair‑Friendly Routes
accessibility.content: Use the MTA Accessibility Map to plan elevator‑only transfers.

accessibility.title: Using MTA Accessibility Filters
accessibility.content: Enable 'Accessible Stations Only' in the MTA app for optimized routing.

accessibility.title: Tips for Mobility Needs
accessibility.content: Avoid older stations without elevators; plan extra time for transfers.

mistakes: Boarding an express train when you need a local stop.
Expecting to tap out—NYC subway only requires tap‑in.

faq.q: Is the NYC subway safe at night for solo travelers?
faq.a: Yes, with precautions: stay near the conductor’s car, avoid empty cars, and use well‑lit exits.

faq.q: How much does a subway ride cost?
faq.a: A single ride is $2.90 with OMNY or MetroCard.

faq.q: Can I use Apple Pay or Google Pay?
faq.a: Yes, OMNY supports all major contactless payment methods.
Most lines run 24/7, but frequency drops late at night.
